programmingLanguages.title: Javascript
programmingLanguages.description: My number 1 go-to for anything frontend or backend. I have grown very comfortable doing backend in Node.

programmingLanguages.title: Ruby
programmingLanguages.description: Ruby is where I really cut my teeth and learned application programming. My programming thought process comes primarily from what I learned doing Ruby.

programmingLanguages.title: PHP
programmingLanguages.description: I learned to program first in PHP. I worked Wordpress for a long time. Dabbled in Drupal, and eventually Laravel a bit.

programmingLanguages.title: Bash
programmingLanguages.description: Probably one of the only scripting languages you ever need to know :P

programmingLanguages.title: Python
programmingLanguages.description: Have done some minor things in Python. Have played with Falcon, Flask. Mostly for fun, but never needed it.

programmingLanguages.title: Erlang
programmingLanguages.description: Currently learning and very very interested in Erlang

programmingLanguages.title: Elixir
programmingLanguages.description: Currently learning and very very interested in Elixir

cloudProviders.title: AWS
cloudProviders.description: I use AWS for everything. I stopped using shared hosting and instead went full AWS.

cloudProviders.title: GCE
cloudProviders.description: Learned some GCE for fun. It's quiet simple to use in comparison to AWS.

cloudProviders.title: Linode
cloudProviders.description: Whenever I need a cheap server with good networking throughput, this is the goto.

cloudProviders.title: Digital Ocean
cloudProviders.description: Similar to Linode, DO provides good services at typically better prices than AWS.

devopsSoftware.title: Terraform
devopsSoftware.description: I barely sign into AWS anymore because of TF. Have grown comfortable creating my own TF modules.

devopsSoftware.title: Docker
devopsSoftware.description: Use it for dev, staging, and production environments. Great in combination with ECS.

devopsSoftware.title: Gitlab
devopsSoftware.description: Probably the best thing since sliced bread. Gitlab will tempt you to drop Jenkins forever.

devopsSoftware.title: Github
devopsSoftware.description: A dev without a github is not a dev.

devopsSoftware.title: Bitbucket
devopsSoftware.description: Used it for a bit for private repos before I discovered Gitlab.

devopsSoftware.title: Kubernetes
devopsSoftware.description: Haven't gone beyond basic tutorials just yet. K8 requires a lot of attention. There is a lot to learn in this world.

frameworks.title: Hapijs
frameworks.description: ExpressJS is a joke compared to Hapi. THE nodejs server framework. Battle tested. Don't look anywhere else, trust me.

frameworks.title: Reactjs
frameworks.description: Do I know facebook's overtly complicated solution to the DOM's need for client side templating? Of course I do. Do I love it? Nope. But I know pretty well (by force :P).

frameworks.title: Riotjs
frameworks.description: The free internet's superbly simple solution to client side templating. Tiny, elegant, easy to learn. I learned riot in 2 days of the 2 weeks I was learning react -_- .

frameworks.title: Preactjs
frameworks.description: ReactJS's not-annoying little brother. It's like 4kb and actually fun to code. Closer to DOM. More predictable vs React.

frameworks.title: Ruby on Rails
frameworks.description: Rails gave me legs in my programming career. I learned MVC, data structures, good conventions, OOP, and other fantastic principles on Rails.

frameworks.title: Vuejs
frameworks.description: Can't say I've taken Vue for a full ride yet. I honestly preferred Riot's simplicity and familiarity. I tend to run from tools that implement a DSL over DOM.

frameworks.title: Phoenix
frameworks.description: My evolution from Rails to Node has brought me here. It is a skill in development.

frameworks.title: Laravel
frameworks.description: Haven't done much except a couple sample apps, and help friends with their laravel projects. Minimal stuff, but it's very Rails-like, which is cool.

databases.title: MySQL / MariaDB
databases.description: I have a love-hate relationship with MySQL because I know Postgres, but it's a DB I know well.

databases.title: PostgreSQL
databases.description: My goto. Why the entire internet doesn't switch to using Postgres is beyond me.

databases.title: SQLite3
databases.description: The best test database in the world. I use it for integration tests in isolated environments (gitlab runners).

databases.title: MongoDB
databases.description: Great for cache. Used it as a serious DB once and couldn't stand it's non-relational attributes so I switched to PG.

expertise.title: PHP
expertise.description: Used to proficient but it's been a while

responsibilities: Fullstack using HapiJS

Support legacy jQuery code

TDD

Develop internal dev tools, CLI tools, etc.

API that supports previously built technologies, a custom admin, using modern web development tools and
libraries, over an AWS infrastructure.
Upgraded and organize development workflow.
Took the lead in research and implementation of technological infrastructure.
Setup development environments for other developers and team members.

Abstracted WordPress from its norm and create custom plugins for enhanced security and custom functionality.

Manage AWS (Route 53, CloudFront, S3, EC2, IAM, SES, SQS, SNS, RDS, etc).
Lots of MySQL database management and migrations.
Implemented Auto-Scaling and Load Balancing on apps.
Worked on AWS Lambda for basic computational / decoupled services (NodeJS).
Custom work with Leaflet map API and Google Maps API.
Worked with the newer Postgres JSONB data types and created custom queries.
Setup server management functions and deployments using Capistrano
Create WordPress Plugins and Themes for clients
Worked on a Code Igniter project
Worked a couple Laravel projects
Deploy Wordpress to AWS, WP Engine, and shared hostings
Worked various Ruby on Rails projects
Deploy Rails projects on Heroku, AWS Beanstalk, etc
Use Capistrano for simple server management
Work with Bootstrap / Zurb Foundation
Built my own CSS frameworks
Produce landing pages
Created an angular 1 streaming radio player
Front end Ruby on Rails building a social network on the first take of the project.
Websockets chat using Pusher
Consume 3rd party API for chat suggestions (amazon, ebay, wikipedia, etc)
Later converted into a stories publication, for which I created a WordPress app.
